title: 109_hr5254
content: The Act is titled the "Refinery Permit Process Schedule Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines key terms such as "Administrator," "applicant," "biomass," and "Federal refinery authorization," which includes various authorizations required for refinery operations under Federal law. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a refinery as a facility that processes crude oil or coal through various chemical or physical processes to produce gasoline or distillate. A refinery is a facility that processes crude oil or coal through chemical or physical processes to produce gasoline or diesel. A State is defined as a State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or any other U.S. territory. SEC. 3. STATE ASSISTANCE. The Administrator can provide financial assistance to States for hiring personnel with expertise in fields relevant to Federal refinery authorizations. Federal agencies can also offer technical or legal assistance to States upon request. SEC. 4. REFINERY PROCESS COORDINATION AND PROCEDURES. The President appoints a Federal coordinator to oversee responsibilities under the Act. Federal and State agencies must cooperate with the coordinator for refinery authorizations. Within 30 days of notification, a meeting is convened with representatives from all relevant agencies for a Federal refinery authorization. The governor of a State must identify agencies responsible for Federal refinery authorizations. A memorandum of agreement must be established within 90 days to coordinate the completion of all authorizations, ensuring compliance with Federal law. If a relevant agency is not represented at the meeting, the Federal coordinator will take action. The Federal coordinator ensures scheduling of Federal refinery authorizations, prioritizing EPA requirements. A memorandum of agreement must be published in the Federal Register within 15 days. All parties must work in good faith to carry out the agreement. The Federal coordinator maintains the schedule with cooperation from Federal and State agencies. The Federal coordinator works with Federal and State agencies to maintain a consolidated record of decisions on refinery authorizations for judicial review. The United States District Court has exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions for review. The United States District Court has exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions for the review of agency or official failure to act on a Federal refinery authorization according to a schedule established in a memorandum of agreement. Applicants or parties to the agreement can bring a cause of action if failure to act jeopardizes timely completion of the schedule. The Court will review if parties have acted in good faith and if the applicant has cooperated fully with the agencies. The Court will establish a new schedule if a failure to act jeopardizes timely completion of the memorandum of agreement, ensuring a coordinated and expedited process while enforcing any schedule set. When a civil action is brought, the Federal coordinator must file the consolidated record with the Court. The Court will expedite the review of any civil action brought under this subsection. SEC. 5. DESIGNATION OF CLOSED MILITARY BASES. The President must designate at least 3 closed military installations for potential refinery construction within 90 days of this Act. One site must be designated for biomass refining. The redevelopment authority for each designated installation must consider refinery feasibility. The Secretary of Defense must prioritize refinery siting when managing and disposing of real property at designated installations. The redevelopment authority for closed military installations must prioritize refinery siting based on recommendations in the redevelopment plan. Real property management and disposal for refinery siting must follow the base closure law. Definitions for base closure law and closed military installation are provided. The term "closed military installation" refers to a military base that has been closed or approved for closure under a base closure law. SEC. 6. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not affect environmental laws or the ability to bring legal action under them. SEC. 7. REFINERY REVITALIZATION REPEAL. Repeals a section of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 related to refinery revitalization.
